intro: Virgulus patens var. georgianus, commonly known as the Georgia virgulus, is a rare and lesser-known plant species native to specific regions of the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodland floors or along stream banks. Its small, white or pale yellow flowers bloom in late spring, contributing to its ornamental value. Due to habitat loss, it is considered endangered and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
